channel.name: What is the maxTransactionsWithActions option in the Reducer?

messages.content: How does it affect a number of the constraints in the contract, and what happens when pendingActions contain more transactions than maxTransactionsWithActions? What is the way to process actions in batches, and is there a limitation on the number of unprocessed actions?

I have this description:

**maxTransactionsWithActions (optional, number)**: Defines the upper limit on the number of actions to process simultaneously. The default value is 32. This constraint exists because o1js cannot handle dynamic lists of variable sizes. The max value is limited by the circuit size.

Exceeding this limit in the pendingActions array triggers an error. 

Unprocessed actions are stored in the archive node, which, to the best of my knowledge, doesn't have a similar limitation.
I am currently working on enabling "dynamic" actions and reducers that will let you reduce **any** number of actions using recursion
at the cost of proving time
Thanks a lot!

Will you also enable a predictable order of actions in reducer? In some cases, it is important to have a predictable order of the actions that are processed by the reducer. I mean that if you call fetchActions() to get actions from the archive node, it would be good if the order of actions were the same as in reduce()

The other question - will it be possible to have several different types of actions in one contract, like in the case of events? Now, it is possible to achieve this by putting some flag in the action indicating the type of the action and then filtering the actions in the reducer using this flag. This leads to long computations.
I see! Tagging @o1martin for this as he mostly worked on the archive node

The protocol doesn't differentiate between different actions, it has only one field assigned to it - so I doubt this will happen anytime soon. The only change I could image would be an API change in o1js, but this would also result in more complex computations as you would have to differentiate between different action types that all are defined by a single hash - but this could also be implemented using recursion

The actions returned by the Archive Node API should always be the in the order they are dispatched by the zkapp. Unless o1js does something different in both these places, the order should be the same. Can you provide an example of this happening?

No, I don't have the example, I'm just relying on the documentation that is saying that the order of the actions in undefined:
```
Because multiple actions are handled concurrently in an undefined order
```
https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/o1js/actions-and-reducer
Will test it to see what happens on Berkeley in reality.
If the order is different coming from the archive node vs the onchain order, you would arrive at a invalid precondition, which would make you unable to rollup the actions
Yes, the order must be correct
The order is undefined wrt when they were dispatched
Because it's a blockchain - order of txs is decided when the block is produced
Also, fetchActions is what you use for reduce, so those two can't be different

@DFST you can also use Protokit, in a way its similiar to what @Florian is working on. But with extra utilities for state management and other advanced ways to reason about your rollup via transactions and runtime modules. 

But the base idea remains the same - dispatch actions, use sequence state, process actions recursively, submit proof of processing actions (settlement)

Yes, I'm thinking about the proof of the actions processing. My idea is to fetch the actions off-chain from the archive node, then calculate recursive proof for the Merkle Map transition given actions data, having as public input the old Merkle Map root, new Merkle Map root, count of the actions, and sum of hashes of the actions (or hash of actions that is possible for the order of actions being fetched from archive node and provided on-chain being the same). 
Then, on-chain using reduce(), I plan to verify the count and sum of hashes of actions, and in case the verification passes, verify the proof and update the on-chain root. 
I plan to publish an example SmartContract in February for discussion, but given the answers in this thread, it should work in theory.

This is exactly what Protkit's protocol does! Except using the o1js's api of `.reduce(...)`, we just use `ZkProgram`. In our model we combine support for various mempools too - either sequence state of private mempool. And the 'hash of an action' is refered to as 'transaction commitment' in our protocol.

We also paralelize processing of state updates (merkle map operations) and business logic (runtime method), we do all the proving in paralel as well. And we settle the 'rollup proof' which we call 'block proof' to an L1 settlement contract.
Yes, I will also need ZkProgram to calculate recursive proofs in addition to SmartContract
Yes, that's a fun exercise. We've spent 6+ months working on an abstraction of a sufficient level to enable an easier developer experience than having to roll-your-own-rollup with zk program
Now it's time to allow ProtoKit chains to be deployed on the serverless cloud so every zkApp developer can enjoy it easily and without full-time node running costs!

Yes, we plan to eventually offer that too - but we have to be careful to not create further unnecessary centralization either. There are additional philosophical details to consider when offering a rollup as a service.
In some cases, not everyone might need a full app-chain - we have a solution for that coming soooon

As promised, I've created an example of the contract that uses Actions to get requests to add entries to the Merkle Map and then, with the help of the reducer, updates the Merkle Map root on-chain using recursive proof.
The code is at https://github.com/dfstio/merkle-map-demo/blob/endActionState/src/mapcontract.ts#L126

@gregor @Florian @o1martin can you please take a look at it and provide your comments?

The code works perfectly on the local blockchain, but on the Berkeley testnet, it does not work when the number of unprocessed actions exceeds maxTransactionsWithActions.

I've raised issues on github on it:
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/1426
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/1427
See also good explanation at https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1205243930870812692/1206070289956470855
Thanks for raising these

Finally, I was able to reduce 64 actions on Berkeley successfully:
https://minascan.io/berkeley/tx/5JuD7TLARm9ZkbMoiKNk8XxMnPbBff3E73sbUqtskNTCXXR96Fds?type=zk-tx

Time spent to calculate and merge 64 proofs: 8 min (528294 ms)
Time to send reduce transaction for 64 actions: 2 min (122280 ms)
Total time for reducing 64 actions (it is about 128 proof calculations) - 10 minutes

That doesn't look right to me @DFST 
The actionState Precondition isn't set at all, so you don't connect your reduction to any on-chain state 🤔

Can you please elaborate on it?
actionState is being checked on the line
https://github.com/dfstio/merkle-map-demo/blob/endActionState/src/mapcontract.ts#L140
and the actions being processed are hashed, counted, and compared with the hash and count on the recursive proof.

I don't have time to debug this unfortunately, but the accountUpdate you are emitting doesn't have a precondition set. You need this because otherwise the initial action hash is not asserted anywhere and a malicious prover could inject any value they want. Normally I'd say the reducer API should do this, but I saw in the transaction that it wasn't set. See `body.preconditions.account.actionState`: It is null, it should be the initial action hash

I understand now. Yes, the precondition for an account.actionState is not set as I process the actions in batches, and to do so, the skipActionStatePrecondition is set to true:
https://github.com/dfstio/merkle-map-demo/blob/endActionState/src/mapcontract.ts#L170

But I have in the account state actionState variable that should correspond to the first action I'm being processing.
I don't need account.actionState for two reasons:
- I want to be able to send reduce() at the same time as other users are adding new actions
- I want to be able to process actions even in the case when the number of unprocessed actions is higher than maxTransactionsWithActions

unfortunately this is not how sequence state is meant to be used, i suggest to read the original RFC: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/265

... or just use Protokit since we take care of abstracting all of this behind the scenes 🙂

Your actionState variable can only save the latest already reduced hash. This is so you know up until which point you already reduced. All the pending actions are appended to the account's actionState, which can happen concurrently (since it happens on-chain). But in order for this to stay safe and have a provable connection you obviously have to assert it in your accountupdate. Otherwise anyone can reduce anything they like 😄
yep, getActions can return pretty much any actions, entirely made up by the person proving the method. this way you have no connection to the dispatched actions

> I want to be able to send reduce() at the same time as other users are adding new actions
Not true - because the precondition checks that there exists a matching value in the last 5 accountStates (hence why you have 5 accountstate fields). Check the RFC and zkapps MIP for more details on that

> I want to be able to process actions even in the case when the number of unprocessed actions is higher than maxTransactionsWithActions
You can't - except if you recurse over it off-chain - statically sized circuits remember. Thats what protokit does for example, we basically recalculate the actionhash offchain with recursion so that we later can assert the on-chain action state hash and assert it's validity

To successfully reduce the actions:
- The hash and count of the actions are being checked
- The signature of the contract owner is being checked
- The proof and public input of the proof, containing the hash and count of actions being reduced, old Merkle Map root, and new Merkle Map root is being checked.

I do not see here the possibility of reducing anything other than actions in the batch.

Well, I was able on the local blockchain to send 16 actions and then reduce them all in 6 calls to the reduce(), max 3 actions in every batch:
https://github.com/dfstio/merkle-map-demo/blob/endActionState/tests/contract.test.ts
It works pefectly in my tests.
hash of the actions can be entirely made up, there is no on-chain connection in the way you tried to use it, its not how it was intended to be used, check the RFC ^^

I agree with you, the Proof is connected with the value you use the smart contract, and you correctly assert the state values, connect them with the Proof, all good.
However there is 1 place in your logic where there is a hole, which is not correctly asserted. 
So what you are basically trying the prove is a transitions from a State A to State B. Actions allow you to translate a problem of `A -> B` into `A -> S1 -> S2 -> S3 -> B`, where Si are some intermediary states (i.e. states after each individual action). 
In order to reduce you have to do multiple things:
1. check that state A is a valid on-chain state
2. check that all inputs to prove a transitions from `Si -> Si+1` are coming from a previously appended action that is included in the Mina on-chain state.
3. prove the correctness of each transition `Si -> Si+1`, and by inductive property `A -> B`
4. set the new state B to an on-chain state.
And crucially, you don't check (2) anywhere. Anyone can provide any inputs to the state transitions, which leads in the pending actions not being provably honored by the rollup method

You can't just erase provable connections if there are limitations. Everything that is not proven will be exploited, it has to be connectable via proofs (i.e. provable code) end-to-end without any room to inject malicious values
skipActionStatePrecondition is also important as it allows us to avoid the situation when the contract is bricked due to the number of unprocessed actions being higher than maxTransactionsWithActions

That is a known limitation / security implication that we have to work with due to the reducer API not yet being recursive. It will be brickable if you use it without recursion, also why we built protokit. But skipActionStatePrecondition is even worse and not a solution, it is a even bigger security hole

Yes, thank you for this comment; it makes sense. It seems like there should be added the code that calculates the hash of all actions, including the subset of the actions being reduced, something similar to
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/main/src/lib/fetch.ts#L1026 and checked against the account.actionState.

I will think on it, maybe will add second proof.

At protokit, we basically rebuilt a Reducer API for handling L1 messages that are dispatched through actions, exactly because of the issue of not being able to rollup when more than maxActions actions are dispatched in one block
I am certain @gregor can back me up on this limitations, would be curious on how mina plans to solve these issues myslef
What is worse than a bricked contract?🤣
nothing 🙂
The only solutions that fixes this at the moment is off-chain recursive reduction, which is kinda what Protokit does

the contract wont get bricked if you follow the same architecture as Protokit does, which allows you to prove an arbitrary amount of actions required to catch up with the sequence state precondition on chain. Currently youre halfway there with the merkle map proof, we call this the state transition proof in our circuits
You don't use reduce() in ProtoKit, so you don't have the limitation on maxTransactionsWithActions?

Yep we don't, we do the same thing reduce does in-line, but instead we pluck it out into a separate circuit that can be executed recursively.

STProof (tree updates) + Runtime proof (logic inside .reduce(...)) = Block proof (with 1 tx)

and then block proof + block proof = block proof

This way we can process an arbitrary number of actions
Understand now, good idea🔥
Ready to come to the dark side? 😉

There is no dark side of the moon really))
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CJvSzJphgT8

embeds.title: PINK FLOYD  THE VOICES OF DARK SIDE OF THE MOON
embeds.description:
. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .VOICES  &  CREDITS  &  RELATED  FACTS   (in clip order)  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
   Dark Side Of The Moon is what happens in 1972 when you mix four Floyd's with a Parsons, 16  tracks and the keys to the door. We've all listened to Dark Side of The Moon wondering, what is that in the background? So,...

messages.content:
We don't use the built-in Reducer-API. 
basically what we do is we apply the actions recursively and at the same time reconstruct the actionHash in the same way as the L1 does, so that we can then later assert if they are the same as the on-chain actionState. 
The idea is that we do the same as the o1js Reducer class, but instead of having a fixed-sized loop bounded by maxActions, we do it via recursion which allows us to do it as many times as there are actions to process.

I assert it here:
<https://github.com/proto-kit/framework/blob/8d40b3e9b5bfe8712d9449a14fb6474754c5db12/packages/protocol/src/settlement/SettlementContract.ts#L279>
Don't let yourself mislead you on where the `newPromisedMessagesHash` comes from, it's a bit more complicated in reality, <https://github.com/proto-kit/framework/issues/83> here is the detailed spec on how we do this

If you are curious to learn more about how we do this exactly, happy to expand more on that.

I've got an idea; it is very good, and I will look into your code. It is similar, as I understand, to what @gregor is doing in his example: https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1205243930870812692/1206623376853049395
Kinda yeah - we also have merklelists, since in the end the L1 actionHash is a commitment to a merkle list
its worth mentioning that this is only the tip of the iceberg, the framework itself does a lot more under the hood in order to make this paradigm work, especially around state updates

How do you fetch actions on Berkeley? With 64 actions, I'm getting.
```
Error: Failed to derive correct actions hash for B62qmWinDr5Z6mNTLhrmYJaVpT5VkAvzPj2yNMpgvZW2tG7ecVcNAME.
        Derived hash: 11392659607867302873244569908690517604138773974349851353190893855519814090686, expected hash: 7366339278787003767281242398340472748631268186800160701517812152175737604920).
```
kind of error for 40 minutes after the last action tx and for 128 actions - more than an hour after the last action tx.
Do you fetch directly from graphql bypassing Mina.fetchActions?
what was the hardware cost for these proofs? or what CPU are you on?

8,143 sec * 8 GB * $0.0000166667 for every GB-second = $1, or 0.8 cents per proof
AWS lambda x86
and what CPU was that on and what was the constraint size?

8225 rows (13% of max 65536 rows)
AWS does not disclose the type of the processor, but in my experience, it is 5x slower than M2 Max
This discussion is 🔥 !

Just have sent a tx on the Berkeley testnet that reduces 128 actions:
https://minascan.io/berkeley/tx/5JuQ2hzqBMJGc2BcMNAxPgX3VaSLNGJctMzELJhViPcjdXJSTSkS?type=zk-tx

Time spent to calculate and merge 128 proofs: 15 min (956016 ms)
Time to send reduce transaction for 128 actions: 2 min (143389 ms)
Total time for reducing 128 actions (it is about 256 proof calculations) - 17 minutes
Billable AWS time:  14,516,089 ms

That's really slow.  Good to have a baseline, but it seems unrealistic to have a free service with many users (assuming we'd need a very expensive sequencer to juice this performance to usable).  Protokit guys - do you know if price per proof is similar for an app chain?

price per proof doesnt depend on if its Protokit or not, i believe price per proof at some server providers i checked out, could be at 0.005$ or less, 0-2^16 constraints ofc each circuit size takes different time to prove. half a cent for the largest circuit - and thats just the price from the first server provider i looked at. that means maybe 0.015$ per transaction, give or take
another parameter you need to count with is the time to settlement, the slower you want to settle your l2 state the cheaper the transactions can be

Well price per proof is variable by speed and complexity right, but it sounds like we could expect similar performance from protokit?  128 proofs per 15 min is like 8-9 actions per minute (with a huge latency).  I can't think of many apps that happy to process 10 actions per minute, even if it's a massive improvement over the nave L1 performance.  So is it not viable to run an app chain on a hobbyist budget?
You can use blocks, and it will be significantly cheaper and faster

There are multiple factors here at play that we have to consider. 
First is that the computing power needed is proportional to the transaction volume. Using cloud providers, this also means that the cost to operate is proportional to the transaction volume. That means that if you charge transaction fees, you should always be able to cover your costs. 
Secondly, there is what we call time to settlement, which basically is the latency to when your appchain will be proven on the L1. This latency scales logarithmically to your transaction volume. That mean that for every doubling of volume, you add one proving step (assuming you have unlimited parallelization available - again, easy with cloud workers), so as an example, if a batch goes from 128 to 256 transactions, the latency only increases by 20 seconds or so. 
Thats gives us pretty nice properties for scaling an appchain. In the case of protokit, the throughput bottleneck isn't even proving anymore, but rather sequencing (which is basically just the process of ordering and executing the transactions sequentially without proving)

Great discussions here, I just wanted to add @45930 that there's no reason why 1 action = 1 proof. If the per-action logic is small, you should be able to reduce 100s of actions per proof. If it's larger, maybe 10s of actions.

In the example I posted earlier (which does very little work per action), a proof for 100 updates with actions takes 18s on my medium-grade desktop, and each update can contain 2 actions, so that's 18 / 200 = 0.09s of proving time per action. Native backend could be 10x faster
https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1205243930870812692/1206623376853049395

@gregor yep the processing of actions can be groupped into one circuit, but thats difficult to abstract and in our current model were doing 1 runtime method = 1 zk program method, but tree updates are maxed out per circuit size

with use of dummies action could be a huge variant as well potentially arriving at a better performance, we can compose runtime methods into a single circuit and process 1-n actions together within one proof as long as they fit into the circuit cc @rpanic, could yield performance improvements since log complexity of proving?

There is also another solution to this problem. We can introduce the concept of eventually synced state and add to the contract Bool state variable that is true if account.actionState is equal to the last processed action hash - endActionState.

For example, we have maxTransactionsWithActions set to 100 and skipActionStatePrecondition to true, and the usual number of unprocessed actions is in the 10-20 range. This way, all the processed actions will always be verified against the account.actionState.

If temporarily, we will see an increase in demand and the number of unprocessed actions will be 1000, then we will need 10 reduce txs to process all those actions. The first nine txs will set this Bool variable to false, so we will understand that the state is not synced yet, but the last 10th tx will send it again to true.

@rpanic  @gregor what do you think about this design?

We address this issue on a settlement to settlement basis, at each settlement we take a snapshot of actions that need to be processed in the next settlement. That way we have a bounded set of actions to prove and not a moving (although historical) target of actionState.
Therefore the system we designed is capped in terms of actions to process by L1 throughput between settlements.

The system you describe with skipping the action state precondition has no on-chain link on reduce to reduce basis, that was the original issue @rpanic raised. Even if you eventually catch up, anything in between isn't linked to anything on-chain, therefore can't be relied upon.

As far as I understand, it is linked as soon as I catch up, and all those 9 reduce() calls will be proved to be correct as I maintain an additional actionState variable that points to the last action processed.

there is no point in doing a reduce-to-reduce basis on the L1, you have to pay transaction fees for it too, you might as well process all that needs to be processed and settle. how sequence state precondition works is that when you settle, you have to be matching the sequence state from n-5 (or 4 + 1 for n) blocks. then you have to consider your proving capabilities and speed, which might make you prove for an n-6 blocks sequence state therefore making your precondition invalid. this is why we take snapshots of the sequence state at every settlement, so that the next settlement does not have to work with a moving target
Can you please elaborate more on " In the case of protokit, the throughput bottleneck isn't even proving anymore, but rather sequencing"? How did you achieve this?

theoretically if every block is 3 minutes, and you have 3min*5 sequence states to catch up, you must prove your L2 batch in under 15minutes to match the last possible sequence state precondition. we tried to generalize the design and that is why we have the snapshot mechanism in place

this is due to how our VM/protocol is designed, currently the sequencer produces:
1. unproven blocks (fast)
2. traced blocks (slow, here we precompute everything required to paralelize proving, but it happens sequentially in the current model, but we do have several improvements in the works to speed it up too)
3. paralelized proving of a proof tree, in the current implementation processing 64 user transactions would require a tree of at least 2^7, meaning 128 proofs at the base level and then 127 merge proofs to complete the tree to the final block proof. With dynamic scaling each level of the proof tree can be completed in paralel, therefore there is 7 levels that have a potentially sequential dependency - even this isnt exactly accurate as our pipeline begins to merge proofs as soon as they are ready (a free worker is available).

So to recap at 64 user transactions, a proof tree of 2^7 meaning 64 runtime proofs + 64 state transition proofs + 127 merge proofs = 255 proofs in total. Each level in the tree has half the proofs than the level below, we start at 128 -> 64 -> 32 -> 16 -> 8 -> 4 -> 2 -> 1

therefore at height 7 we have 8(?) sequential merging steps, at a reasonably powerful CPU of like 3-4ghz and 8-10 cores, the biggest circuits (merge or 2^16) will take <15 seconds in the wasm prover so therefore to complete the proof tree its 8*15 secons = 2 minutes to prove 64 user transactions thanks to our architecture

very rough estimates here so apologies if there are mistakes, but the principles stay the same, in the current model the tracing itself might take more time than the proving, since it cant happen in paralel until we implement all the planned improvements to our tracing implementation.

i can't leak any more alpha here 😄 only after you start contributing to Protokit!

This logic is clear. I use the same on this simple example by precomputing all the values and then by proving them in parallel. You cannot do the proving in parallel if you do not know the result of all calculations in advance before the proving.

By saying that "sequencing is the bottleneck" do you mean 2) step? It is quite fast in comparison to the proving - it should take seconds, and proving should take minutes even when being done in parallel.

The second question: how do you manage memory? Currently, there are some memory leaks, and o1js can create a maximum of 100-200 proofs; then, you should restart the worker. Otherwise, the worker will freeze due to the memory shortage. On serverless, it is done automatically through the mechanism of cold starts, but how do you handle it on the ProtoKit server?

The difference between your demo code and what the Protokit sequencer does is the level of abstraction provided for the developers working with it. The way we designed runtime + protocol enables the exact same experience as developing on EVM or Substrate.

When it comes to cloud workers, we are working on dockerized workers with auto scaling, its a small step forward from the current in-memory single machine proving pipeline implementation, the underlying message queue enables a quick shift from the development environment to a distributed cloud environment with little to no devops effort. It's all baked in, waiting for the next small step in development. If there are mem leaks, we can relaunch the workers and connect them to the message queue again, or trigger manual garbage collection, or a combination of both depending on the lifespan of the worker.

I think this is ultimately a race to the bottom as there's no technique we have discovered as of yet, that'd improve the performance outside of the things we've mentioned or have planned internally. In the end both yours and ours implementation will meet at the proving level, where we will produce a similiar amount of constraints. Going to AWS Lambda, or a different server provider is only a matter of cost, and lambda will always be the more expensive option.

What are the methods of manual garbage collection? The only way I've found so far is to make small 100ms delays before proving. It increases the probability for the garbage collection to run by allowing for extra cycles of GC, but it does not always work - sometimes, it works perfectly, and sometimes it does not work at all. I do not understand the other factors; I guess it can be related to the o1js binding mechanism. The only explanation I've found is from node v8 engine developer:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52740509/can-garbage-collection-happen-while-the-main-thread-is-busy
theres an option when running nodejs to expose a manual gc API
Can you point me to the example?
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/30674757/running-garbage-collection-manually-in-node

embeds.title: Running garbage collection manually in node
embeds.description: I am using node and am considering manually running garbage collection in node. Is there any drawbacks on this? The reason I am doing this is that it looks like node is not running garbage collection

messages.content: might be viable for workers
or simply spawn a new worker per proof
